header.title: Ambivalence toward Christianity in the Kabbalah of Abraham Abulafia
header.category: Western Esotericism, Kabbalah, Jewish Mysticism, Christian Mysticism

central_thesis: This dissertation investigates Abraham Abulafia's conflicted stance toward Christianity, demonstrating how his overt hostility coexisted with a profound, often subconscious, absorption of Christian doctrines. Abulafia integrated key Christian motifs into his unique Kabbalistic system, particularly regarding his messianic self-conception and the figure of Jesus. This ambivalent relationship, rooted in deep psychological struggles and castration anxiety, formed the subtext for his mystical doctrine, driving his quest to overcome self-other dichotomies and achieve redemptive internal synthesis by subsuming the 'forbidden other' (Christianity) within a Jewish framework.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction: Abulafia and Alterity; the Other in the Self
structure_content.summary: This chapter establishes Abulafia's central internal conflict regarding Christianity, viewing it as a 'forbidden other' that nonetheless held a powerful, anxiety-inducing attraction. It introduces the psychoanalytic lens, framing Abulafia's mystical quest as a struggle to transcend the self-other dichotomy and achieve internal reconciliation, paralleling rabbinic discussions of R. Eliezer's attraction to sectarianism. The discussion contextualizes Abulafia's experiences within broader medieval inter-group dynamics and the theoretical frameworks of Geertz and Kristeva regarding identity formation and the 'foreigner within'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter One: Refutation and Absorption; Abulafia’s Response to the Christian Context
structure_content.summary: This chapter details Abulafia's explicit anti-Christian polemics, which echoed contemporary Jewish arguments, often characterizing Christianity as carnal, idolatrous, and demonic (linked to Esau). Concurrently, it demonstrates Abulafia's surprising absorption of Christian doctrines, including Trinitarianism and the concept of 'speaking in tongues'. His reinterpretation of these motifs within a Jewish mystical framework, particularly through letter permutation and the identification of the Holy Spirit with the Active Intellect, reveals a complex strategy of refutation intertwined with absorption.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Two: Abulafia’s Demons; the Psychological Dimension of Abulafia’s Relationship to Christianity
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores Abulafia’s demonology, linking his battles with demonic assailants to his internal struggle with Christian influences. Demons are identified as 'obstructions' originating from the imaginative, non-intellective aspects of the Active Intellect, testing the mystic's 'refinement'. The chapter argues for a psychoanalytic interpretation, highlighting Abulafia's castration anxiety stemming from his attraction to the 'forbidden other' (Christianity) and the perceived threat of emasculation through idolatry. His self-proclaimed fifteen-year 'trial' is presented as a period of intense psychological torment related to this conflict.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Three: Abulafia and Jesus; Metatron and Sandalfon
structure_content.summary: This chapter analyzes Abulafia's complex identification of Jesus with the demonic Sandalfon, the 'Prince of the Backside' and the evil inclination, contrasted with Metatron, the 'Prince of the Countenance' and the Jewish messiah (Abulafia himself). It demonstrates how Abulafia parses the Tetragrammaton into YH (Jewish messiah/intellect) and VH (Jesus/imagination), embodying a bipartite divine nature. The chapter shows how the mystical goal involves integrating these opposed aspects, with Jesus often representing the seductive, imaginative component to be subdued or absorbed for messianic self-realization.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Four: Warp and Woof; Circumcision, Crucifixion and Divine Embodiment
structure_content.summary: This chapter examines Abulafia's reinterpretation of 'sheti va-‘erev' (warp and woof) as a cruciform structure, linking it to the Teli and circumcision. It argues that Abulafia consciously co-opted Christian crucifixion symbolism, seeing the 'True Cross' not in Jesus's physical suffering but in the spiritual dimensions of Jewish circumcision, which completes the divine name and reconstitutes the mystic's phallic potency. This reinterpretation serves as a polemic against Christian corporeality and reflects Abulafia's profound, often erotic, ambivalence toward the 'forbidden' Christian body, culminating in the concept of divinized flesh and blood.

The conclusion summarizes Abulafia's enduring messianic thought as a quest to eradicate dichotomies and achieve internal synthesis. It reiterates that his perceived mission to unify faiths, though thwarted externally, was enacted internally through the reconstitution of self. The work highlights that Abulafia's embrace of the 'forbidden other' (Christianity) was not merely a weakness but a strategic imperative to incorporate and transcend perceived heresy, ultimately affirming the absolute unity of the Godhead and the holistic nature of the Tetragrammaton, where the 'idolatrous VH' is embraced as part of the unified self.

key_concepts.definition: A unique mystical system developed by Abraham Abulafia focusing on ecstatic experience, prophetic revelation, and self-divinization through intensive meditation on language, particularly letter permutation (Tseruf) of Hebrew and other alphabets, to achieve conjunction with the Active Intellect.

The divine emanation or cosmic mind, identified with Metatron, that the mystic seeks to unite with. Abulafia conceives it as bipartite, containing both intellective/good (Metatron) and imaginative/demonic (Sandalfon) aspects, which must be discerned and integrated.

The concept of a distinct external group or entity, specifically Christianity for Abulafia, which serves to define Jewish identity. However, Abulafia's personal attraction to Christian doctrines and motifs blurs these boundaries, transforming the external 'other' into an internal psychological struggle.

Abulafia's core meditative technique involving the systematic combination, reordering, and numerical analysis (gemaṭria) of letters, primarily Hebrew, but also other languages. This practice is believed to unlock divine wisdom, purify the mystic's being ('refinement'), and lead to prophetic states and communion with the Active Intellect.

Personified representations of internal doubts, errors, and idolatrous temptations that assail the mystic during meditative practice. These are often linked to the imaginative faculty, the evil inclination, and specifically, to Christian doctrines, posing a threat to the mystic's spiritual and physical integrity.

A psychoanalytic concept applied to Abulafia's deep-seated fear of physical harm or mutilation (especially loss of the phallus, symbolizing covenantal insignia and masculine identity) as a divine punishment for illicit desires or attraction to idolatrous/feminizing Christianity. This fear is a central psychological dynamic in his mystical system.

A kabbalistic term, literally 'warp and woof', used by Abulafia to describe the interwoven, bipartite nature of cosmic entities, the mystic's being, and covenants. It often implies a cruciform structure and represents the integration of opposing elements (e.g., masculine/feminine, good/evil, spiritual/corporeal) within a unified whole.

Abulafia's belief in his own role as the Jewish messiah, a divinized figure who achieves prophetic revelation and aims for universal religious unification. This self-conception is profoundly shaped by and often involves the reinterpretation or 'usurpation' of Christian messianic figures like Jesus.

Abulafia's unique formulation of a divine triad within a Jewish monotheistic framework, often by parsing the ten Sefirot into 'Holy Spirit', 'Father', and 'Son', or by using linguistic constructions (like three-fold speech) that mirror Christian Trinitarian concepts, while simultaneously polemicizing against Christian polytheistic interpretations.

A miraculous prophetic ability central to Abulafia's system, where the mystic, through communion with the Holy Spirit (Active Intellect) and letter permutation, gains understanding of and the capacity to prophesy in all seventy languages of the nations, drawing a direct parallel to the New Testament account of the Apostles.

A demiurgic celestial constellation in Kabbalah, identified by Abulafia with the Active Intellect and the serpent. It possesses both 'front' (good/divine) and 'back' (evil/demonic) aspects, and is often linked to Jesus in its material, imaginative, and idolatrous dimensions, which the mystic must confront and integrate.

The ninth Sefira, known as the 'Foundation', intimately associated with the phallic potency, procreation, and the Active Intellect in Abulafia's system. It is crucial for the mystic's divinization and the 'giving of fruit' to the lower world, contrasting with Jesus's 'impotent' or 'fetid' aspects.

Abulafia's controversial notion that God's essence and names can manifest physically, or 'become flesh made word', often through the Torah and its letters. This concept, while seemingly anti-Maimonidean, allows Abulafia to absorb and reframe Christian incarnationism within a Jewish mystical context, often linked to circumcision and the mystic's own body.

practical_system.description: Abulafia’s system, known as Prophetic or Ecstatic Kabbalah, is an operative path aimed at achieving ecstatic union (devequt) with the Active Intellect and prophetic revelation. This is attained through a process of 'refinement' and 'reconstitution of self', involving the mastery and integration of inner opposites (e.g., intellect/imagination, good/evil, masculine/feminine), often in confrontation with external 'idolatrous' influences. The ultimate goal is self-divinization, messianic status, and the eradication of dichotomies within the mystic's being, leading to a state of profound unity.
tools: Hebrew Alphabet: The fundamental tool for letter permutation and gemaṭria.
Gemaṭria: Numerical analysis of letters and words to reveal hidden connections, equivalences, and esoteric meanings, often used to validate mystical insights or polemical arguments.
Sefer Yeṣirah: A foundational Kabbalistic text providing the cosmological and linguistic framework for understanding the Sefirot, creation, and letter permutations.
Knowledge of Sefirot: Understanding the ten divine emanations and their internal configurations (e.g., bipartite nature, male/female aspects) as a roadmap for mystical ascent and self-transformation.
Active Intellect: The divine source of inspiration and the object of mystical conjunction. The mystic must engage with its complex, often dualistic, nature.
Biblical and Rabbinic Texts: Sacred scriptures (Torah, Psalms, Exodus, Daniel) serve as sources for prooftexts, allegories, and encrypted divine names for meditation and hermeneutical analysis.

Inner Psyche (Intellect and Imagination): The mystic’s own mental faculties are both the arena and instruments of the practice, requiring sharp discernment to differentiate between pure intellective influx and deceptive imaginative products.
rituals: Letter Permutation (Tseruf): The core practice involves manipulating Hebrew (and other) letters in various combinations and sequences to unlock hidden divine names and esoteric meanings, inducing ecstatic states. This is often described as 'revolving' or 'turning over' letters.

Contemplation of Divine Names: Intense focus on the numerical values and inherent qualities of God's names (e.g., Tetragrammaton, Shaddai) to discern divine intentions, structure the cosmos, and achieve prophetic insight.

Mystical Trials ('Refinement'): Engaging with internal 'demonic' or 'idolatrous' phantasms (often identified with Christian doctrines or the imaginative faculty) as necessary tests. The mystic must discern intellective truth from imaginative delusion, aiming to 'subjugate' or 'harmonize' these challenging elements.

Body-Letter Correspondence: Manipulation of letters is intimately linked to the mystic's body, where letters correspond to limbs. This practice aims for bodily refinement and alignment of the microcosm (mystic's body) with the macrocosm (sefirotic structure), leading to a 'divinized flesh' or 'flesh made word'.

Wearing Tefillin: Used in mystical rituals, particularly the hand tefillin, whose 'knot' symbolizes the restriction of base sexual impulses. Its 'untying' (not literally) represents the liberation of sexual potency and its sublimation into a binding with the divine.

Vocal and Aural Practices: The permutation of letters is often accompanied by specific intonations, and the resulting prophetic experience is described as 'hearing the voice of God' and 'speaking in tongues', allowing the mystic to understand and prophesy in seventy languages.

relevant_quotes.text: This dissertation is devoted to an investigation of the conflicted attitude toward Christianity demonstrable in the writings of the kabbalist Abraham Abulafia (1240 – ca. 1291). Abulafia’s hostility toward Christianity is explicit and emphatic. ... Abulafia’s ambivalent feelings toward Christianity ran to the core of his psyche, providing the subtext for his mystical doctrine and sense of his own messianic mission and demonstrating the role of the forbidden other in the construction of self.

Very literally, as we shall see, Abulafia is plagued by inner demons. These demons are representations of the alien, forbidden other. Abulafia sought to overcome the crisis that the attack by demons represented in a fashion reminiscent of the pattern discussed above with respect to the theosophical kabbalists. That is, Abulafia sought an internal reconciliation, one which would annihilate the distinction between self and other.

And I saw many terrible and wonderful visions through signs and wonders, and because of them jealous spirits gathered around me. And I saw imaginings and errors and my reason was panic-stricken, because I could not find a single man who would teach me the way to go. And so I was like a blind man groping at midday for fifteen years, with Satan standing at my right to mislead me.

And he comes upon you and asks you to give to him his portion from yourself, and he is half of your existence, speaking allegorically, and he seeks to cut off your limbs, one after the other, and you see it all with your eyes. And thus you despise all of your limbs and all of their bodily powers because of the fear of God who gives to the angel of death his fixed portion that is hinted at [in] that he is Satan and he is the angel of death and he is the evil inclination and he is the imaginative power in the heart that rules over your mind, and he is clever in doing evil, and he does not know the doing of good. And he besieges your heart in the matter of confounding [bilbul] heart and heart [lev ve-lev]. And sometimes he is revealed to you to kill you and to devour your circumcision [livloaʻ milatkha] if Zipporah, the wife of Moses, does not help you to be (Ex. 4:26) “a bloody bridegroom because of the circumcision;” and she circumcised the foreskin of her son in the taking of a sharp stone and in the cutting of the covenant.

Now he is describing this process as the means by which the mystic is afforded the opportunity to become transubstantiated as the divine name, to become flesh made word. Wolfson has observed the kabbalistic strain of thought in which flesh is transubstantiated as word, or as Torah, the inverse of the Christian modality in which the Logos is corporealized.

This weaving together of these two aspects of the Teli we understood, after Idel and Wolfson, in erotic terms. The latter frames this erotic dimension as the reconstitution of the phallic potency achieved through the integration of male and female dimensions, from which we may understand Abulafia’s reference to his “flesh” – that is, his phallus - in the aforementioned passage. As well, the equation, via gemaṭria, of “my flesh” with “twenty-two” letters results, we saw, from the mystic’s divinization subsequent to his phallic reconstitution, represented as the weaving together of the head and tail of the Teli. This is achieved via recourse to the mystical manipulation of the letters, which conform directly to the mystic’s own body. Abulafia conveys the notion that a divinization occurs by indicating that the expressions “in my flesh” and “Prince in me” share the same consonants. That the Prince – Metatron – dwells within the mystic is representative of the latter’s coming into both a divinized and a messianic status.

Since his attraction to Christianity bears the imprint of erotic fascination, it is fitting that Abulafia locates the true cross in the phallus. We might fairly say that Abulafia covets what the Christians possess in their doctrine of the crucifixion, and that this envy becomes centered for him around notions of the phallus.

To perceive the idolatrous VH as a counterposed element within the Tetragrammaton was, then, to commit that very heresy of idolatry which it epitomized. For Abulafia, then, that element - which signified Christendom above all else - was somehow to be embraced, in no way any longer as other, but as self. From this we may come to understand that Abulafia, at a deep level, confronted his Christian milieu with the sense that to experience heresy strictly as such was the quintessential heresy.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to Western Esotericism for its deep psychoanalytic exploration of a foundational Kabbalist's inner world, demonstrating how external religious polemics and internal psychological conflicts dynamically shaped mystical doctrine. It provides a technical and nuanced understanding of how Abulafia engaged with, absorbed, and reinterpreted Christian motifs (e.g., Trinity, incarnation, crucifixion) to formulate his unique ecstatic Kabbalah. The analysis highlights the permeable boundaries between traditions, the concept of 'inward acculturation,' and the profound psychological underpinnings of magical and mystical practice, particularly regarding identity formation and the confrontation with the 'forbidden other'. This offers a significant contribution to understanding the syncretic nature of esoteric traditions and the subjective experience of the occultist.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes advanced scholars and researchers in Jewish Studies, Western Esotericism, Comparative Mysticism, Religious Studies, and Psychoanalytic Theory. Practitioners of Qabalah and related magical traditions will also find this analysis valuable for its insights into the psychological and operative dimensions of Abulafia's system, particularly regarding the challenges of confronting 'demonic' or 'heretical' influences in their own practice.
